P.GENERICRANGE: LMM is known around the world as the creator of the Anne of Green Gables books, an enormously popular series of novels written primarily for children about a red-headed girl growing up in Prince Edward Island, Canada. In addition to some novels aimed at a more adult audience, she also produced undistinguished poetry and some journalism. Her voluminous diaries have also attracted critical attention, and she maintained lengthy correspondences with friends Ephraim Weber and George MacMillan.

AUTHORSUMMARY.P: LMM's writing tends to romance instead of realism, and she criticised the novel Strange Fugitive by Morley Callaghan for creating a literature that focused solely and meticulously on a latrine or pig-sty. 160 The point of literature, she thought, was to focus on the beautiful: sunsets are just as real as pigsties. 161

SHORTPROSE.P: The author commented that, contrary to popular opinion, she never called herself Lucy Maud: my friends called me Maud and nothing else. 77 She also did not like her given name, I always liked Maud—spelled not with an e if you please—but I do not like it in connection with Montgomery. 2: 67

CHRONPROSE.BIRTHPOSITION: LMM was born in Clifton, Prince Edward Island, Canada, her parents' only child.

SHORTPROSE.P: LMM was a white Canadian of Scottish and English heritage. In matters of religion, she said she was sceptical of the notion of a higher authority and once described herself as having no faith—a peculiar statement for a woman who became the wife of a Presbyterian minister. However, she apparently fulfilled the public role of a minister's wife with aplomb, describing it as a privilege and not a duty. 100 In private she wrote that the position was one thrust upon those whom the gods wish to destroy. 117 LMM believed in one thing rather different from Presbyterian beliefs—reincarnation.80, 121 121

Although one Boston magazine described her as a conservative in politics, with no favour for woman suffrage, 85 LMM argued that a woman with property of her own should have a voice in making the laws. 86 She did think the majority of women would be happiest at home, but she firmly advocated education for girls in an 1896 article written for the Halifax Herald. There she celebrates the fact that nowadays . . . a girl is no longer shut out from the Temple of Knowledge simply because she is a girl. 87
Women in the Maritimes had access to education for some thirty years before LMM wrote her article. Nova Scotia in 1864 introduced the Free School Act which made public schooling available to a greater number of children, and Mount Allison University—one of the first to do so—began admitting women as early as 1862.
LMM's mother, Clara Macneill Montgomery, was twelve years younger than her husband and died of consumption when her daughter was just under two years old.121

Her father, Hugh John Montgomery, was a shopkeeper. When his wife died, he sent the young LMM to be raised by her grandparents, Alexander and Lucy Woolner Macneill, where she grew up among a large extended family. Eventually her father moved to Sakatchewan, where he started a new life with a second wife and children. He died there in 1900.121-2

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMM visited her father and his new family in Prince Albert, Saskatchewan after arriving by rail with her paternal grandfather, Senator Donald Montgomery.

SHORTPROSE.P: She was treated badly by her stepmother, who thought her a handy babysitter and housemaid. Her half-brother, Carl, later lost a leg at Vimy Ridge during World War One. She revisited western Canada in 1930.105 22, 87

LMM attended a one-room schoolhouse across the road from her grandparents' farmhouse, completing her time there in 1892. The following year, she went to the Prince of Wales College in Charlottetown for teacher training. Her course of studies was varied, ranging from English literature and rhetoric to agricultural management. An essay she wrote there was used at graduation and printed in the local newspaper. Her favourite authors included Dickens, the Brontës, Thackeray, George Eliot, Edward Bulwer-Lytton, and Elizabeth Barrett Browning.2:8 18, 26, 27, 34, 121, 122

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMM spent this year teaching at Bideford, Prince Edward Island

SHORTPROSE.P: LMM saved enough money to attend Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia. for one year, 1895-1896, where her studies included Milton and Carlyle. She wrote for the school newspaper and joined a literary society.29, 36, 122

When her savings ran out, she left university and by the next year she was teaching again in Belmont, P.E.I. Among the influential books she read in the next few years were Olive Schreiner's The Story of an African Farm and Charlotte Brontë's Jane Eyre.29, 36, 122 A voracious reader for life, she also nurtured interests in astronomy and needlework, once winning a prize for her lace designs at the Canadian National Exhibition.96, 102

LMM was briefly engaged to Edwin Simpson, a theology student and a third cousin. Their engagement ended shortly after she began a passionate relationship with a farmer named Herman Leard. She boarded with his family while teaching for a year at Lower Bedeque, P.E.I. Although she was strongly attracted to Leard, she implied that class differences prevented her from marrying him. She described the attraction in a letter: He had no brains, no particular good looks, in short, nothing that I admire in a man. Yet I loved him as I never can love any other man. 92 Leard died in June 1899, roughly two years after their involvement.30, 33, 39, 122

A recent publication, The Intimate Life of L.M. Montgomery, 2005, contains essays which minutely examine her relationships with Leard (a hyperbolic tale of passion masking a story of frustrated desire),131 her husband, and other intimate friends and correspondents.

In 1906 LMM became engaged to solid, sensible Ewan Macdonald, who had recently taken a position as minister of the Presbyterian church at Cavendish, P.E.I. They could not marry until her dependent grandmother no longer needed LMM's assistance and until after Macdonald returned from graduate studies in divinity at the University of Glasgow.42, 122

During this interval, LMM functioned as the town postmistress, taking over duties from her grandmother, and was also the organist at the church where she met Ewan Macdonald. During this period she wrote and profited from her best-known work, Anne of Green Gables.40, 47

Despite her early publishing successes, she was prone to bouts of depression. In 1909 she recorded in her journal her sufferings from nervous prostration—an utter breakdown of body, soul, and spirit. 50 1: 392

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMM married Presbyterian minister Ewan Macdonald; she was thirty-six and her new husband forty.

SHORTPROSE.P: She recorded her reaction to the wedding in her journal: Something in me—something wild and free and untamed—something that Ewan had not tamed—. . . rose up in one frantic protest against the fetters which bound me. 2: 68 After a honeymoon in Scotland and England, the couple settled in Leaskdale, north-east of Toronto, Ontario.123

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMM gave birth to her first son, Chester Cameron Macdonald, at the age of thirty-eight.

SHORTPROSE.P: Chester became a lawyer, but lost his position in a legal partnership, separated from his wife, and was unemployed and living in the basement of his mother's house at the time of her death.A7

P.CHILDREN: A second son, Hugh Alexander, born in August 1914, died at birth, but another healthy son, Ewan Stuart was born the following year. Stuart became a doctor, married, and had children.

SHORTPROSE.P: LMM's husband suffered from depression. He had his first breakdown in the summer of 1919.124
Cats were always an important part of LMM's family. How dreadful it would be not to love a cat! she wrote in a letter.127

During the 1920s, LMM and her husband fought against the proposed merging of the Presbyterian and Methodist churches. In January 1925, the Leaksdale church, under the leadership of Macdonald, voted against union.78
Shortly after this, LMM's husband accepted a new posting in Norval, Ontario, which meant a move closer to Toronto.80
LMM's fame brought her into contact with a variety of interesting people. For instance, in September 1910, she was invited to Charlottetown to meet with Governor General Earl Grey.83

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMM met novelist and suffragist Nellie McClung, but thought her rather lacking in subtlety.136

SHORTPROSE.P: Around the same time she also met Emmeline Pankhurst and described her as resembling a Presbyterian elder's wife who has done nothing more strenuous in her life than putting up with the elder and running the [Women's Missionary Society]. 3: 29 Canadian poet Bliss Carman she praised as a survival from the Golden Age. 3: 397 136-7

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMM was contacted by British prime minister Stanley Baldwin, who hoped to meet her on his upcoming trip to Canada.

SHORTPROSE.P: Baldwin declared himself a huge fan at festivities in Toronto that included the Prince of Wales and Prince George. A later British prime minister, Ramsay MacDonald, claimed that he had read all of her books several times over.157 83
Around 1925, LMM began experiencing asthma attacks.79

She suffered from depression in the late 1930s, exacerbated by financial troubles, her children's misadventures, and her husband's poor mental health. He suffered a complete breakdown in the summer of 1934 which necessitated a three-month stay in the Homewood Sanatorium in Guelph, Ontario. This was followed by her own collapse in 1938: she was unable to work, eat, or sleep. A second episode occurred in 1940.97, 127 182, 185

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMM died in Toronto, Ontario, where she had lived, largely unhappily, for seven years In September 2008 her grand-daughter reported the family belief that she took her life by means of a drug overdose.

SHORTPROSE.P: The death certificate said coronary thrombosis. Her son Stuart found a sheet of paper by her bedside which he interpreted as a long sucide note. He responded by keeping her presumed suicide a secret out of loyalty to her memory. Her biographer Mary Rubio thinks that the sheet of paper (numbered page 176) was the ending of a final journal, the rest of which is missing, and that while LMM had been feeling suicidal it cannot be known whether or not she killed herself.A7 She was buried in a cemetery at Cavendish, Prince Edward Island, Canada; her husband died the following year. Not till 2008, the year of centenary celebrations for the publication of Anne of Green Gables, did her grand-daughter decide that revealing the secret would do more good, in raising public awareness of mental health issues, than continuing to keep it.127 F1, F6

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: LMM, The Selected Journals of L.M. Montgomery, 1985-2004

CHRONPROSE.PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY: LMM began keeping a diary and started writing poetry at the age of nine.

SHORTPROSE.P: She kept the diary for the following fifty-five years in addition to responding daily, in the years following her success, to copious fan mail.162 Among other early endeavours were biographies of cats and dolls, histories of visits, descriptions of favourite haunts, and critical reviews of books. 17 These were all destroyed by the young author. She had a difficult time obtaining writing materials, and her first poem was written only when she happened upon some discarded post-office letter bills. Her early efforts to secure writing material are mirrored in another young writer Emily Byrd Starr, heroine of the Emily trilogy. Neither LMM's father nor her teachers were at all impressed with her early literary attempts.17

P.PINFLUENCESHER: Her writing, like Emily's, was profoundly influenced by nineteenth-century English writers and poets. LMM named Hemans and Byron in personal letters; Emily cites Tennyson and Wordsworth.

PPERIODICALPUBLICATION.PPLACEOFPUBLICATION: LMM 's writing appeared in print for the first time; her epic poem about a French sea captain was published in the Charlottetown Patriot.

P.PMATERIALCONDITIONS: At Prince of Wales College in Charlottetown a few years after this,
P.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: she wrote an essay on Shakepeare's Portia which was read out at the graduation ceremonies and printed in the Charlottetown Guardian.
P.PEARNINGS: In 1904, LMM made five hundred dollars for her prose writing.

PATTITUDES.PMOTIVES: She described her ambitions at this time like this: I want to be a good workman in my chosen profession. I cannot be one of the masters but I hope to attain to a recognized position among the everyday workers of my time.

P.PMOTIVES: She rigorously exploited the writing market by pursuing every possible outlet and consciously tailored her writing to different demands. About one story she wrote, I shall be ashamed of it but shall expect a liberal check.

SHORTPROSE.P: LMM is best known and revered for her creation of a red-headed orphan named Anne Shirley. Though she had faith enough in the first Anne novel to keep revising it and sending it out, she was also quick to dismiss its importance, calling it a juvenilish story, ostensibly for girls. 71 She was later surprised when reviewers responded to the text as if it were meant for adult readers.71, 76

RBESTKNOWNWORK.RLANDMARKTEXT: LMM received notice from L. C. Page Co. of Boston that they wished to publish her novel for young adults entitled Anne of Green Gables; it was out by June of the following year.

P.PSUBMISSIONSREJECTIONS: She had sent off the manuscript with great trepidation because it had already been rejected five times.

SHORTPROSE.P: Anne is placed with a forbidding, elderly brother and sister who had asked for a male orphan to help with work on their farm on Prince Edward Island. She is bubbly, well-intentioned, imaginative, and constantly getting into scrapes.

The novel had six editions before November 1908; its instant success brought sometimes unwanted celebrity to the author. She was pleased, however, to receive an admiring letter from Mark Twain. Many of the reviews in the US, Canada, and Britain were positive, and the novel retained its popularity over the years even when other books by LMM fell out of favour. Millions of copies have been sold, and the book has been translated into fifteen langauges, finding particular favour with Korean and Japanese readers. Anne's story has been adapted for theatre, film, and (by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) television, and is the foundation of an entire cultural industry centred around Cavendish, P.E.I.. 50 71-72, 73, 74, 76 xvii In early 2008 there appeared several centenary publications. Elizabeth Rollins Epperly edited Imagining Anne: The Island Scrapbooks: more than a hundred pages from LMM's personal scrapbooks kept between 1893 and 1910, including photos, visiting cards, cuttings, and pressed flowers. Irene Gammel traced the genesis of the Green Gables story in Looking for Anne: How Lucy Maud Montgomery Dreamed Up a Literary Classic. LMM's family commissioned from Nova Scotia author Budge Wilson an official prequel, Before Green Gables . This relates (in Wilson's own voice, not a pastiche of Montgomery's) the story of Anne's first ten years, how she became an orphan and how she became tough and endearing. In the same year Anne of Green Gables was for the first time included in the prestigious Modern Library series, published in New York. D9

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMM published a sequel to her successful novel Anne of Green Gables: Anne of Avonlea.

P.PRELATIONSWITHPUBLISHER: The second Anne book was written to please her publisher.
P.RSELFDESCRIPTION: Writing a sequel that she had not anticipated cemented LMM's dislike of that detestable Anne. The idea that she would be compelled to follow Anne's life in fiction all the way to college, she wrote, makes me sick.

SHORTPROSE.P: LMM wrote sequels until there were eight Anne books in total, and did in fact follow Anne to college in Anne of the Island (published in 1915) and beyond: Anne's House of Dreams covers the early years of her marriage and Rainbow Valley chronicles Anne's children as they grow up. Rilla of Ingleside, ostensibly about Anne's youngest daughter but meant as a tribute to the girlhood of Canada, was intended as the last in the series, penned in 1920.79 However, two non-sequential novels about Anne's early adult life (Anne of Windy Poplars and Anne of Ingleside) appeared in the late 1930s. LMM yearned to be free of her heroine's success, explaining that the fictional creature weighed on me like an incubus when she ceased to be an inspiration. 79

P.PEARNINGS: This series was a huge financial boon for the still-unwed LMM. In 1910, for example, her royalty payments were $7,000. However, because of loopholes in the orignal contract, she made no money when the story of Anne was turned into two movies and a number of plays.

P.TGENREISSUE: LMM's Kilmeny of the Orchard, 1910, began as a short story but expanded rapidly into a romance for young readers.

SHORTPROSE.P: Scottish highland heritage and outsider status are issues for both of the young couple at the centre of this story. Kilmeny Gordon is born after her young mother makes a marriage which she then discovers to be bigamous, and dies from the shame of it. Her baby is left to be brought up by a grandmother who feels her very existence to be a disgrace. Kilmeny grows up beautiful but mute (though not deaf). By the end of the book she has found both her voice and happiness, being about to marry Eric Marshall, a Nova Scotian whose graduation (from a college now also admitting women) occupied the book's first chapter, and who first saw Kilmeny romantically solitary in an orchard playing her violin. Kilmeny was a narrative poem by James Hogg, whose heroine vanishes and spends seven years in the world of spirits before returning, only briefly, to her ain countree.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMM published a novel that she was sorry to finish, The Story Girl.

SHORTPROSE.P: LMM regarded this work, featuring a heroine named Sara Stanley, as more literary than her Anne novels. The episodic plot, which has Sara telling ghost stories to a group of seven children, is regarded by at least one critic as less likely to sustain readers' interest than the Anne or Emily books.81, 84

P.RRESPONSES: The reviews for this work were pleasant and kind.94

CHRONPROSE.PDEDICATION: LMM published a collection of short stories, The Golden Road, and dedicated it to her aunt Mary Lawson.

SHORTPROSE.P: Distracted by new motherhood, LMM had written this book, she said, in in odds and ends of time and so left a disagreeable impression of unfinishedness in my mind. 101 Perhaps it was for this reason that the book was a collection of short stories instead of a sustained narrative; she had used the same form for Chronicles of Avonlea the previous year.103
In 1916 Toronto's McClelland and Stewart published a book of LMM's verse entitled The Watchman and Other Poems.103

P.PSERIALIZATION: LMM related the story of her own career in The Alpine Path, which appeared serially in a Toronto magazine, Everywoman's World, in 1917.
P.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: She had previously published short stories in magazines such as the Canadian Magazine and Everybody's Magazine.
P.PRELATIONSWITHPUBLISHER: In 1920 a number of these stories were collected without her consent by L. C. Page, her unscrupulous first publisher, who was able to assemble a new publication from her: Further Chronicles of Avonlea. LMM responded with a lawsuit that dragged on for more than ten years, alleging, among other things, that she was treated particularly poorly because she was a woman writer. After a bitter dispute that reached the Supreme Court of the United States, LMM won her case against the Boston publisher.

P.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: LMM was asked by Canada's Chatelaine magazine to write an article about contemporary girls. It appeared in the March 1931 issue.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: A novel aimed by LMM at adult readers, The Blue Castle, appeared this month.

TSETTINGPLACE.TGENREISSUE: It was set in Ontario's Muskoka region and later marketed as a children's book.

SHORTPROSE.P: LMM's only other fiction intended unequivocally for adults was A Tangled Web, about a family's struggle for the possession of an heirloom jug. In England it was sold under the title Aunt Becky Began It. 164

CHRONPROSE.RRESPONSES: LMM published the first novel in the Emily trilogy, Emily of New Moon; it was regarded as her most successful creation since Anne of Green Gables.

P.TCHARACTERIZATION: Emily was a character much closer to her creator's heart than Anne. LMM admitted to autobiographical aspects of Emily: People were never right in saying that I was Anne, but, in some respects, they will be right if they write me down as Emily. 134 Unlike the orphan Anne, Emily grows up in a tangle of family traditions. She also has a passion for writing, which she feels both instinctively and physically through what she refers to as the flash—a moment when the curtain is drawn back to reveal a glimpse of the enchanting world beyond, a moment that came rarely—went swiftly, leaving her breathless with the inexpressible delight of it. 7 Thus the Emily series is as much about the birth and development of an artist as it is about the growth and maturation of a woman.

SHORTPROSE.P: The sequels Emily Climbs and Emily's Quest followed in 1925 and 1927.41, 45
Other fictional works by LMM include Magic for Marigold which appeared in 1929, the Pat series, begun in 1933 with Pat of Silver Bush, and Jane of Lantern Hill, published in 1937.125-7

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Publication began of The Selected Journals of L. M. Montgomery, edited by Mary Rubio and Elizabeth Waterston in five volumes. The last appeared in 2004.

PMATERIALCONDITIONS.PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY: Her kept her journals by filling a volume with transcriptions of passages written on odd scraps of paper.

P.PNONSURVIVAL: Though the published journals run until 1942, Mary Rubio believes that a further sequence having to do with the years from 1939 onwards was written but has never been found. One possibility is that her son Chester destroyed it after her death, knowing or guessing that it would be highly critical of his behaviour. A7

P.RRESPONSES: LMM's grand-daughter Kate Macdonald Butler later wrote that she sobbed through the final volume, which records the clinical depression both of the author and of her husband.F6

SHORTPROSE.P: In 2012 the selected journals were joined by the first volume of the complete text, by the same editors, Mary Rubio and Elizabeth Waterston: The Complete Journals of L. M. Montgomery: the PEI Years 1889-1900. The same editors issued the second volume, still in PEI and covering 1901-1911, in 2013.

P.TTONESTYLE: In this unabridged version the picture of LMM's life is much darker.

SHORTPROSE.P: Benjamin Lefebvre has edited two volumes of The L. M. Montgomery Reader, 2013-14 (the second volume being subtitled A Critical Heritage).

CHRONPROSE.RRECOGNITIONS: LMM was the first Canadian woman to become a Fellow of the British Royal Society of Arts.

P.RRECOGNITIONS: In 1935 she was not only admitted to the Literary and Artistic Institute of France but also received the OBE in England.172 102

The following year saw the opening of Green Gables, a national park devoted to the fictional world created in the Anne books. LMM explained that even though Green Gables was based on several of her childhood homes, and not just the one singled out by the park commission, she was pleased to see this particular farm and the surrounding area with its trees and lanes preserved exactly as they are. 181

P.RSHEINFLUENCED: Playwrights Alice Chawicke and Wilber Braum both turned Anne into three-act plays in 1937.182

CHRONPROSE.RRECOGNITIONS: A Canadian postage stamp was launched with an illustration of LMM's most famous character, Anne, and the name of the author.

P.PARCHIVALLOCATION: LMM's letters to Ephraim Weber and George Boyd MacMillan are in the National Public Archives of Canada. She resisted the idea of having her biography written, calling the undertaking a screaming farce. I know I wouldn't want some of my soul moods depicted, she continued, for the evil ones would shame me and the good ones would be desecrated by revelation. 77 prelims

The largest collection of LMM's personal letters are housed in the special collections of the University of Guelph library. TheGuelph archive includes: journals (1889-1942), scrapbooks, corresponedence, photographs, and the original manuscript of Rilla of Ingleside.
